Used adverbially or as a preposition with genitive. Apparently, this is the basic expression for 'near' in Plato. Cf. the main examples for the direct meaning 'near (spatial)' (note esprecially the instances where ἐγγύς is opposed to the basic term πόρρω 'far'):    _x0015_Laws 5.745c "he must divide up both the city itself and all the country into the twelve portions <...> He must mark off 5,040 allotments, and each of these he must cut in two and join two pieces to form each several allotment, so that each contains a near [ἐγγὺς] piece and a distant [πόρρω] piece", "надо разделить на двенадцать частей и самый город, и всю страну <...> Всех наделов устанавливается пять тысяч сорок. Каждый из них опять-таки делится на два участка: близкий [ἐγγὺς] и дальний [πόρρω]"; Laws 5.745e "each citizen must take as his share two dwellings, one near [ἐγγὺς] the center of the country the other near the outskirts. Thus the settlement shall be completed", "Каждому гражданину следует отвести два жилища: одно - близ [ἐγγὺς] срединной части государства, другое - на окраине"; Prot. 356c "Does not the same size appear larger to your sight when near [ἐγγύθεν], and smaller when distant [πόρρωθεν]?", "одно и то же по величине кажется вам на вид вблизи [ἐγγύθεν] больше, а вдали [πόρρωθεν] меньше, не так ли?"; Prot. 356e "Well now, if the saving of our life depended on the choice of odd or even, and on knowing when to make a right choice of the greater and when of the less - taking each by itself or comparing it with the other, and whether near [ἐγγὺς] or distant [πόρρω] - what would save our life?", "А если бы благополучие нашей жизни зависело от правильного выбора между четным и нечетным - от того, что один раз правильно будет выбрать большее, а другой - меньшее независимо от того, больше оно само по себе или по сравнению с чем-нибудь другим, вблизи [ἐγγὺς] ли оно находится или вдали [πόρρω], - то что сберегло бы нам жизнь? Не знание ли?"; Phaedo 113a "The third river flows out between these two, and near [ἐγγὺς] the place whence it issues it falls into a vast region burning with a great fire and makes a lake larger than our Mediterranean sea"; Rep. 10.615d "'For indeed this was one of the dreadful sights we beheld; when we were near [ἐγγὺς] the mouth and about to issue forth and all our other sufferings were ended, we suddenly caught sight of him and of others, the most of them, I may say, tyrants", "когда после многочисленных мук были мы уже недалеко [ἐγγὺς] от устья и собирались войти, вдруг мы заметили Ардиея и еще некоторых".    _x0015_The word ἐγγύς 'near' can also be used metaphorically, e.g.:    _x0015_Apol. 38c "you see how old I am, how far advanced [πόρρω] in life and how near [ἐγγύς] death"; Soph. 234e "Therefore all of us elders here will try, and are now trying, to bring you as near [ἐγγύτατα] (to the truth) as possible without the sad experience", "Поэтому-то все мы здесь постараемся, да и теперь стараемся, подвести тебя к ней (к истине) как можно ближе [ἐγγύτατα] прежде, чем ты испытаешь такие воздействия".    _x0015_A second candidate is the preposition/adverb πλησίον [Brandwood 1976: 749], but its meaning should rather be deemed as specifically 'next to, close', e.g.:    _x0015_Prot. 315d "Prodicus was still abed, wrapped up in sundry fleeces and rugs, and plenty of them too, it seemed; and near [πλησίον] him on the beds hard by lay Pausanias from Cerames", "Продик был еще в постели, укрытый какими-то овчинами и покрывалами, а на одной из соседних [πλησίονs] с ним кроватей расположился керамеец Павсаний"; Phaedo 59d "We used to meet at daybreak in the court where the trial took place, for it was near [πλησίον] the prison", "Мы и до того - и я, и остальные - каждый день непременно навещали Сократа, встречаясь ранним утром подле суда, где слушалось его дело: суд стоит неподалеку [πλησίον] от тюрьмы"; Phaedo 117a "Thereupon Crito nodded to the boy who was standing near [πλησίον]", "Тогда Критон кивнул рабу, стоявшему неподалеку [πλησίον]"; Phaedrus 227b "Yes, at Epicrates' house, the one that belonged to Morychus, near [πλησίον] the Olympieum", "Да, у Эпикрата, в доме Морихия близ [πλησίον] храма Олимпийца".    _x0015_The frequent adverb σχεδόν [Brandwood 1976: 856] normally means 'about, approximately', 'almost' and so on. The adverb πέλας [Brandwood 1976: 731] is normally used in the substantivized meaning 'neighbor(s)'. The adverbs ἐγγύθεν, ἄγχι (ἀγχοῦ) are not attested in Plato.

Cf. some examples:    _x0015_Tim. 60d-e "the other, which blends well with the combinations which affect the sensation of the mouth, is that substance which is customarily termed 'beloved of the gods,' namely 'salt' [ἁλῶν]", "Вторая же разновидность весьма хорошо включается во вкусовые ощущения рта и представляет собой соль [ἁλῶν]; это любезное богам тело, как именуют ее по обычаю"; "I recollect coming across a book by somebody, in which I found Salt [ἅλες] superbly lauded for its usefulness", "однажды мне попалась книжка одного мудреца, в которой превозносились полезные свойства соли [ἅλες]".

Multiple attestations. Polysemy: 'short (spatial) / short (temporal) / insignificant / in a slight degree'. Cf. some examples:    _x0015_Meno 82e-83a "Tell me, boy, do you say we get the double space from the double line? The space I speak of is not long [μακρόν] one way and short [βραχύ] the other, but must be equal each way like this one, while being double its size - eight square feet", "По-твоему выходит, что, если удвоить стороны, получается удвоенный квадрат? Я имею в виду не такую фигуру, у которой одна сторона длинная [μακρόν], а другая короткая [βραχύ], а такую, у которой все четыре стороны равны, как у этой, но только удвоенную, восьмифутовую"; Theaet. 172d "they do not care at all whether their talk is long [μακρῶν] or short [βραχέων], if only they attain the truth", "если какой-нибудь побочный вопрос более придется им по душе, чем основной, не заботятся о том, долго [μακρῶν] или коротко [βραχέων] придется им рассуждать, лишь бы только дойти до сути"; Soph. 263c "Now the second of my sentences about you is in the first place by sheer necessity one of the shortest [βραχυτάτων] which conform to our definition of sentence", "Вторая речь, которую я о тебе произнес, прежде всего в силу нашего определения, что такое речь, необходимо должна быть одною из самых коротких [βραχυτάτων]".    _x0015_The adjective σύντομος is attested in the adverbial form συντόμως 'concisely, briefly' [Brandwood 1976: 852]. The adjective κοντός (κονδός) is not attested in Plato.

Cf. some examples:    _x0015_Phaedo 112d "Some flow in on the side from which they flowed out, others on the opposite side; and some pass completely around in a circle, coiling about the earth once or several times, like serpents [ὄφεις]", "Иной раз исток и устье на противоположных сторонах, а иной раз - по одну сторону от середины той Земли. А есть и такие потоки, что описывают полный круг, обвившись вокруг той Земли кольцом или даже несколькими кольцами, точно змеи [ὄφεις]"; Rep. 2.358b "Thrasymachus seems to me to have given up to you too soon, as if he were a serpent [ὄφις] that you had charmed, but I am not yet satisfied with the proof that has been offered about justice and injustice", "Фрасимах, по-моему, слишком скоро поддался, словно змея [ὄφις], твоему заговору, а я все еще не удовлетворен твоим доказательством как той, так и другой стороны вопроса".    _x0015_The noun δράκων is not used in Plato.

Segments: l e p t ó s
Comment: Polysemy: 'thin 3D / thin 2D / small, fine'. Cf. some examples:    _x0015_Crat. 389b "Then whenever he has to make a shuttle for a light [λεπτῷ] or a thick garment", "А посему, если нужно сделать челнок для легкой [λεπτῷ] ткани, либо для плотной, льняной, шерстяной, или какой-нибудь другой"; Rep. 7.523d "Each one of them appears to be equally a finger, in this respect it makes no difference whether it is observed as intermediate or at either extreme, whether it is white or black, thick or thin [λεπτός], or of any other quality of this kind", "Каждый из них одинаково является пальцем - в этом отношении между ними нет никакой разницы, все равно, смотришь ли на его середину или край, белый ли он или черный, толстый или тонкий [λεπτός] и так далее"; Tim. 59b "And the kind which closely resembles gold in its particles but has more forms than one, and in density is more dense than gold, and partakes of small [ὀλίγον] and fine [λεπτὸν] portions of earth", "Среди всего того, чему только что было дано название плавких жидкостей, есть и то, что родилось из самых тонких [λεπτὸν] и самых однородных [ὀλίγον] частиц, а потому плотнее всего".    _x0015_The adjective ἰσχνός [Brandwood 1976: 468] means 'lean (of person'). The adjectives ἑανός, ἀραιός are not attested in Plato.

Segments: á n e m o s
Comment: Cf. some examples:     _x0015_Phaedo 58b-c "and sometimes, when contrary winds [ἄνεμοι] detain it (the ship), this takes a long time", "А плавание иной раз затягивается надолго, если задуют противные ветры [ἄνεμοι]"; Phaedo 77d-e "You have the childish fear that when the soul goes out from the body the wind [ἄνεμος] will really blow it away and scatter it, especially if a man happens to die in a high wind [πνεύματι] and not in calm weather", "(вы) испытываете детский страх, как бы и вправду ветер [ἄνεμος] не разнес и не рассеял душу, когда она выходит из тела, - в особенности если человеку выпало умирать не в тихую погоду, а в сильную бурю [πνεύματι]"; Theaet. 152b "Is it not true that sometimes, when the same wind [ἀνέμου] blows, one of us feels cold, and the other does not?", "Разве не бывает иной раз, что дует один и тот же ветер [ἀνέμου], а кто-то мерзнет при этом, кто-то - нет?".     _x0015_The noun πνεῦμα [Brandwood 1976: 751] apparently has the specific meaning 'blast, gale' (further 'breath'), as can be seen from the example:     _x0015_Crat. 410b "But is air called ἀήρ because it raises (αἴρει) things from the earth, or because it is always flowing (ἀεὶ ῥεῖ), or because wind [πνεῦμα] arises from its flow? The poets call the winds [πνεύματα] ἀήτας, 'blasts'", "А вот воздух (αήρ), Гермоген, разве не от того ли, что что-то воздымает (αίρει) от земли, называется воздухом? Или, может быть, оттого, что он находится в вечном течении (αεί ρεΐ)? Или потому, что от его течения возникают ветры [πνεῦμα], а ветры [πνεύματα] поэты называют дуновениями (άήται)?".     _x0015_Cf. some other contexts with πνεῦμα :     _x0015_Phaedo 70a "They fear that when the soul leaves the body it no longer exists anywhere, and that on the day when the man dies it is destroyed and perishes, and when it leaves the body and departs from it, straightway it flies away and is no longer anywhere, scattering like a breath [πνεῦμα] or smoke", "Они опасаются, что, расставшись с телом, душа уже нигде больше не существует, но гибнет и уничтожается в тот самый день, как человек умирает. Едва расставшись с телом, выйдя из него, она рассеивается, словно дыхание [πνεῦμα] или дым, разлетается, и ее уже решительно больше нет"; Phaedo 77d-e see above; Tim. 49b-c "First of all, we see that which we now call "water" becoming by condensation, as we believe, stones and earth; and again, this same substance, by dissolving and dilating, becoming breath [πνεῦμα] and air; and air through combustion becoming fire; and conversely, fire when contracted and quenched returning back to the form of air and air once more uniting and condensing into cloud and mist; and issuing from these, when still further compressed, flowing water; and from water earth and stones again", "Но возьмем для начала хотя бы то, что мы теперь называем водой: когда она сгущается, мы полагаем, что видим рождение камней и земли, когда же она растекается и разрежается, соответственно рождаются ветер [πνεῦμα] и воздух, а последний, возгораясь, становится огнем; затем начинается обратный путь, так что огонь, сгустившись и угаснув, снова приходит к виду воздуха, а воздух опять собирается и сгущается в облака и тучи, из которых при дальнейшем уплотнении изливается вода, чтобы в свой черед дать начало земле и камням".     _x0015_The noun πνοή [Brandwood 1976: 751] is attested once, apparently in the meaning 'breath'; the noun ἄημα is not attested in Plato.

Segments: e n i a w t ó s
Comment: There are two rather frequent words for 'year' in Plato: ἐνιαυτός [Brandwood 1976: 352] and ἔτος [Brandwood 1976: 402]. They seem to be fully synonymous, as suggested by the following context:   _x0015_Crat. 410c-d "The seasons, Socrates, and the two words for year [ἐνιαυτὸς καὶ ἔτος] <...> The two words for year, ἐνιαυτός and ἔτος, are really one", "Времена года, Сократ. А также два слова: 'годы' [ἐνιαυτὸς] и 'лета' [ἔτος] <...> А 'годы' [ἐνιαυτὸς] и 'лета' [ἔτος], думаю, есть нечто единое".    _x0015_Statistically, however, ἐνιαυτός and ἔτος tend to be in complementary distribution by number: ἐνιαυτός is normally used in sg., whereas ἔτος is normally used in pl. (it does not mean that the former one is totally prohibited in pl. and the latter one - in sg.). Because of this, we fill the slot with ἐνιαυτός.    _x0015_Cf. some examples for ἐνιαυτός [Brandwood 1976: 352]:    _x0015_Stat. 298e-299a "When the year [ἐνιαυτὸς] of office has passed for each set of rulers, there will have to be sessions of courts in which the judges are chosen <...> anyone who pleases can bring against the captains an accusation for failure to command the ships during the year [ἐνιαυτὸν] in accordance with the written laws or the ancestral customs", "Когда исполнится год [ἐνιαυτὸς] правления каждого из правителей, надо, созвав судилище, состоящее либо большей частью из богатых людей, либо из представителей народа <...> каждый желающий может их обвинить в том, что в течение года [ἐνιαυτὸν] они водили суда, не следуя ни предписаниям, ни древним обычаям предков"; Criti. 116c "Thither also they brought year by year [κατ᾽ ἐνιαυτὸν] from all the ten allotments their seasonable offerings to do sacrifice to each of those princes", "в честь этого ежегодно [κατ᾽ ἐνιαυτὸν] каждому из них изо всех десяти уделов доставляли сюда жертвенные начатки"; Rep. 7.527d "for quickness of perception about the seasons and the courses of the months and the years [ἐνιαυτῶν] is serviceable, not only to agriculture and navigation, but still more to the military art", "потому что внимательные наблюдения за сменой времен года, месяцев и лет [ἐνιαυτῶν] пригодны не только для земледелия и мореплавания, но не меньше и для руководства военными действиями".    _x0015_Cf. some examples for ἔτος [Brandwood 1976: 402]:    _x0015_Phaedo 58b "Now the Athenians made a vow to Apollo, as the story goes, that if they were saved they would send a mission every year [ἔτους] to Delos", "А афиняне, как гласит предание, дали тогда Аполлону обет: если все спасутся, ежегодно [ἑκάστου ἔτους] отправлять на Делос священное посольство"; Gorg. 448a "I may add that nobody has asked me anything new for many years [ἐτῶν] now", "я утверждаю, что ни разу за много лет [ἐτῶν] никто не задал мне вопроса, который бы меня озадачил"; Stat. 307e-308a "in a few years [ἔτεσιν] they and their children and the whole state often pass by imperceptible degrees from freedom to slavery", "часто незаметно для себя самих их дети и все их государство за несколько лет [ἔτεσιν] попадают в рабство".
Corresponds to Ancient Greek hól-o- {ὅλος} 'whole, all (totus)'.

Comment: The former one, steɣn-ˈo-, seems to be the most generic term (it is applied, e.g., to dry cloth), whereas kser-ˈo- rather means specifically 'dry, arid' (applicable to weather or earth) or 'dry' in application to food (e.g., to dry fruits). We prefer to treat steɣn-ˈo- as the basic term.  _x0015_Modern Demotic steɣn-ˈo- {στεγνóς} is cognate to Ancient Greek stegn-ó- {στεγνóς} 'watertight, waterproof'; Modern Demotic kser-ˈo- ~ ksir-ˈo- {ξερóς ~ ξηρóς} is cognate to Ancient Greek kseːr-ó- {ξηρóς} 'dry' (it gradually becomes a basic term for this meaning already in Ancient Greek).

Comment: Before an initial fricative or resonant of the next word, the reduced variant ðe {δε} is used. Originates from the Ancient Greek adverb uː-d-én {οὐδέν} 'not at all, naught', a fossilized neutral form of uː-d-ey-s {οὐδείς} 'no one' < particle uː-dé {οὐδέ} 'but not, and nor, nor' plus the numeral 'one'. The particle uː-dé {οὐδέ} consists of the main negative exponent uː {οὐ} and the general demonstrative enclitic -de {-δε}.   _x0015_Prohibitive is expressed with the particle min {μην} (mi {μη} before an initial fricative or sonant of the next word), which is cognate to the Ancient Greek prohibitive negation méː {μή}. Final -n is the result of influence on the part of negative ðe(n).
Source: A particle, denoting negation of assertion

Paradigm: ˈol-e {ὅλε} [masc.] / ˈo-a {ὅα} [fem.] / ˈoʎ-u {ὅλιου} [neut.]. Polysemy: 'all (omnis) / all (totus)'. Cognate to Modern Demotic ˈol-o- {όλος} 'all (omnis) / all (totus)', Ancient Greek hól-o- {ὅλος} 'whole, all (totus)'. _x0015_Cf. the adjective pˈas-e {πᾶσε} 'many' q.v., whose female gender form pˈas-a {πᾶσα} retains the old meanings 'whole; every' (examples: "I said you the whole truth", "every woman", "every day"). Cognate to Ancient Greek nom. sg. m. pâːs {πᾶς} (< *pant-s, pl. pánt-es {πάντες}) 'all' q.v.

Genitive: spoil-ˈe {σποϊλέ}. Cognate to hypothetical **{σποδίλα}, diminutive from Ancient Greek spod-ó-s {σποδός} 'ashes'. Apparently, this is the basic Southern Tsakonian term for 'ashes' (in particular, it is this one that is listed in [Vyatkina 2015]), cf. some of Deffner's and Kostakis' examples: "leave ashes, we'll make lye", "to become ashes (= to be burnt to ashes)", "to scatter like ashes".    _x0015_Distinct from Southern Tsakonian skˈoɲ-i {σκόνι} with polysemy: 'ashes / powder (a medicine)' [Deffner 1923: 326; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 157]. This seems to be a more rare word: no examples are provided by Deffner and Kostakis. Cognate to Ancient Greek kón-i-s {κόνις} 'dust', kon-í-a {κονία} 'dust', Medieval and Modern Demotic Greek skˈon-i {σκόνη} 'dust'. Initial s- in the Demotic form is secondary, probably due to reanalysis of the combination acc. pl. skˈon-es + definite article tis: tis skˈon-es > tiskˈon-es > ti-skˈon-es (as from tis-skˈon-es) > sg. skˈon-i. Tsakonian skˈoɲ-i 'ashes' implies the same non-trivial morphological process as is observed in Demotic Greek; thus, it is likely that Tsakonian skˈoɲ-i was borrowed from Demotic at a certain stage or at least influenced by the Demotic form. However, the semantic development 'dust' > 'ashes' looks like an internal Tsakonian innovation.

Northern Tsakonian: flˈuð-a {φλοῦδα} 'bark'. Directly cognate to the rare Modern Demotic word flˈuð-a {φλούδα} 'bark', a back formation from Medieval Greek {φλούδιον}, diminutive from Ancient Greek pʰloy-ó-s ~ pʰló-o-s {φλοιός, φλόος} 'bark'. Tsakonian frˈu-a looks adapted from Demotic flˈuð-a or at least influenced by it. In [Vyatkina 2015: 57], only the Modern Demotic loanword flˈuð-a 'bark' is quoted for Prastos.
Cognate to Ancient Greek pʰüsk-eː {φύσκη} 'large intestine', Modern Demotic Greek fˈusk-a {φούσκα} 'bubble; bladder'.

Borrowed from Demotic pul-ˈi {πουλί} 'bird'.

Suppletive paradigm: par̝=ˈi- {παρ́ίου} [pres., imperf., imperfective subjunctive] / e=kˈan- {ἐκάνα} [aor., perf.] / ˈea {ἔα} [imv.] / mˈol- {να μόλου} [perfective subjunctive]. Pres. par̝=ˈi-u is directly cognate to the Ancient Greek participle par=i-óːn {παριών} from pár=ey-mi {πάρειμι} 'to pass by, pass' (< êy-mi {εἶμι} 'to go' with prefixation). Aor.-perf. kˈan- is cognate to rare Ancient Greek hikáː-n-oː {ἱκάνω} 'to come to, reach'. Imperative ˈea is directly cognate to Ancient Greek imperative éla {ἔλα} from elá-oː {ἐλάω} 'to drive, set in motion'. Subjunctive mˈol- is cognate to Ancient Greek é=mol- {ἔμολον} - aorist from the rare suppletive verb blóː-sk-oː {βλώσκω} 'to go, to come'. We treat Southern Tsakonian pres. par̝=ˈi-u and aor. e=kˈan- as synonyms.

Tsakonian pe=nˈa-kʰ-u is directly cognate to Ancient Greek apo=tʰnéː-y-sk-oː {ἀποθνῄσκω} 'to die'.   _x0015_In [Vyatkina 2015: 57], the Modern Demotic loanword pe=θˈen-u is also quoted for Prastos as a parallel form for 'to die'.

The Northern Tsakonian variant is pˈi-n-u {πίνου} 'to drink' [Deffner 1923: 182]. Cognate to Ancient Greek píː-n-oː {πίνω} 'to drink'.

Apparently this is the basic term for 'dry', glossed as 'trocken, dürr / sec, aride, dur'. Cf. the examples: "dry leaves", "dried bread" [Deffner 1923: 365], "dry firewood", "dry grass" [Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 338]. Cognate to Ancient Greek kseːr-ó- {ξηρóς} 'dry'.  _x0015_Distinct from more marginal and specific terms:  _x0015_1) ˈa=bretʰ-e ~ ˈa=brex-o {ἄβρετ̔ε, ἄβρεχο} 'not soaked, dry' [Deffner 1923: 3; Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 6], cognate to Ancient Greek á=brekt-o- ~ á=brox-o- {ἄβρεκτος, ἄβροχος} 'unsoaked, unmoistened'.  _x0015_2) steɣn-ˈe {στεγνέ} 'lean, skinny / dry', application is unknown [Deffner 1923: 333; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 185; Vyatkina 2015: 57], probably borrowed from or influenced by Modern Demotic steɣn-ˈo- {στεγνóς} 'dry'.  _x0015_3) psaxn-ˈe {ψαχνέ}, glossed as 'trocken (Fleisch ohne Fett) / sec' [Deffner 1923: 398], according to [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 373] can also be applied to objects (e.g. cloth); cognate to Modern Demotic psaxn-ˈo- {ψαχνός} 'fleshy, meaty' (sic!).

Segments: a v o t ˈa n a
Comment: Cognate to Ancient Greek ûː-s {οὖς} 'ear'. Final -n-a is a nominal suffix chain. The root avota- is the result of reanalysis of the combination nom.-acc. pl. ôː-t-a {ὦτα} 'ears' + definite article tá {τά}: tá ôː-t-a {τά ὦτα} > tavota > t-avota (as from ta-avota) > avota.  _x0015_Note that Ancient Greek nom.-acc. pl. ôː-t-a {ὦτα} is an Ionic-Attic form; its more archaic variant is úːa-t-a {οὔατα}, attested in Epic and Doric (e.g., Theocritus 22.45, Epicharmus 21). Theoretically, Tsakonian avotˈa-n-a can go back to Doric úːa-t-a {οὔατα} as well: tá úːata {τά οὔατα} > tavata > t-avata (as from ta-avata) > avata > avota with the shift a > o (> u), which is sporadically attested in Tsakonian [Deffner 1881: 143; Pernot 1934: 55].  _x0015_Tsakonian avotˈa-n-a 'ear' implies the same non-trivial morphological process as we observe in Demotic Greek (tá oːtía 'the small ears' > aft-ˈi 'ear'), but the starting points in Tsakonian and Demotic are different, thus it is likely that Tsakonian avotˈa-n-a 'ear' was influenced by the Demotic form at a certain stage rather than directly borrowed from Demotic.  _x0015_Cf. the similar case with Tsakonian avuɣ-ˈo 'egg'.

Segments: a v u t ˈa n a
Comment: Cognate to Ancient Greek ûː-s {οὖς} 'ear'. Final -n-a is a nominal suffix chain. The root avota- is the result of reanalysis of the combination nom.-acc. pl. ôː-t-a {ὦτα} 'ears' + definite article tá {τά}: tá ôː-t-a {τά ὦτα} > tavota > t-avota (as from ta-avota) > avota.  _x0015_Note that Ancient Greek nom.-acc. pl. ôː-t-a {ὦτα} is an Ionic-Attic form; its more archaic variant is úːa-t-a {οὔατα}, attested in Epic and Doric (e.g., Theocritus 22.45, Epicharmus 21). Theoretically, Tsakonian avotˈa-n-a can go back to Doric úːa-t-a {οὔατα} as well: tá úːata {τά οὔατα} > tavata > t-avata (as from ta-avata) > avata > avota with the shift a > o (> u), which is sporadically attested in Tsakonian [Deffner 1881: 143; Pernot 1934: 55].  _x0015_Tsakonian avotˈa-n-a 'ear' implies the same non-trivial morphological process as we observe in Demotic Greek (tá oːtía 'the small ears' > aft-ˈi 'ear'), but the starting points in Tsakonian and Demotic are different, thus it is likely that Tsakonian avotˈa-n-a 'ear' was influenced by the Demotic form at a certain stage rather than directly borrowed from Demotic.  _x0015_Cf. the similar case with Tsakonian avuɣ-ˈo 'egg'.

Meaning 'earth, soil'. Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek xˈoma {χώμα} 'earth', Ancient Greek xôːma {χῶμα} 'earth thrown up, bank, mound'. Tsakonian xˈoma ~ xˈuma looksadapted from Demotic xˈoma or at least influenced by it.  _x0015_A second candidate is yi ~ iyˈi {γῆ, ἰγῆ}, whose meaning is rather 'earth, ground' [Deffner 1923: 94; Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 224], cognate to Ancient Greek gêː {γῆ} 'earth'.  _x0015_Distinct from the adverb xˈamu {χάμου} 'on the ground, to earth' [Deffner 1923: 389; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 335], corresponds to Ancient Greek xamáy {χαμαί}, Modern Demotic xˈamu {χάμου} 'on the ground, to earth'.  _x0015_Probably no direct traces of Ancient Greek kʰtʰóːn {χθών} 'earth' (Epic, Doric).

Meaning 'earth, soil'. Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek xˈoma {χώμα} 'earth', Ancient Greek xôːma {χῶμα} 'earth thrown up, bank, mound'. Tsakonian xˈoma ~ xˈuma looksadapted from Demotic xˈoma or at least influenced by it.  _x0015_A second candidate is yi ~ iyˈi {γῆ, ἰγῆ}, whose meaning is rather 'earth, ground' [Deffner 1923: 94; Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 224], cognate to Ancient Greek gêː {γῆ} 'earth'.  _x0015_Distinct from the adverb xˈamu {χάμου} 'on the ground, to earth' [Deffner 1923: 389; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 335], corresponds to Ancient Greek xamáy {χαμαί}, Modern Demotic xˈamu {χάμου} 'on the ground, to earth'.  _x0015_Probably no direct traces of Ancient Greek kʰtʰóːn {χθών} 'earth' (Epic, Doric).

Suppletive paradigm: čˈu- {τσ̌οῦ} [pres., etc.] / e=fa-ˈi-k-a {ἐφαῆκα} [aor.] / fa- {φάε} [imv., perfective subjunctive]. Pres. čˈu- is cognate to Modern Demotic trˈo-o {τρώω} 'to eat', Ancient Greek tróːg-oː {τρώγω} 'to gnaw, nibble, munch'. Aor. fa- is cognate to Ancient Greek pʰag- {φαγεῖν} 'to devour'. We treat pres. čˈu- and aor. fa- as synonyms. Note that Tsakonian čˈu- looks adapted from Demotic trˈo-o or at least influenced by it.

Segments: e f a ˈi k a

Comment: Cognate to Ancient Greek oːy-ó-n {ᾠόν} 'egg'. The root avuɣ- is the result of reanalysis of the combination nom.-acc. pl. oːy-á {ᾠά} 'eggs' + definite article tá {τά}: tá oːyá {τά ᾠά} > tá oːá {τά ὠά} > taoɣa > tavoɣa > tavuɣa > t-avuɣa (as from ta-avuɣa) > Modern sg. avuɣ-o.  _x0015_Note that Ancient Greek nom.-acc. pl. oːy-á {ᾠά} 'eggs' is an Ionic-Attic form; the expected more archaic Doric nom.-acc. pl. form is óːe-a {ὤεα}, cf., e.g., attested dat. sg. oːé-oːy {ὠέῳ} (Ibycus). Theoretically Tsakonian avuɣ-ˈo can go back to Doric óːe-a {ὤεα} as well: tá óːe-a {τά ὤεα} > taoeɣa > taveɣa > tavoɣa > tavuɣa > t-avuɣa (as from ta-avuɣa) > Modern sg. avuɣ-o with the shift e > o (> u), which is not rare in Tsakonian [Deffner 1881: 143; Pernot 1934: 56].  _x0015_Tsakonian avuɣ-ˈo 'egg' implies the same non-trivial morphological process as is observed in Demotic Greek (tá oːyá 'the eggs' > avɣ-ˈo 'egg'), but the starting points in Tsakonian and Demotic might theoretically be different; thus it is likely that Tsakonian avuɣ-ˈo 'egg' was borrowed from Demotic at a certain stage or at least influenced by the Demotic form.  _x0015_Cf. the similar case with Tsakonian avotˈa-n-a 'ear'.  _x0015_In [Vyatkina 2015: 57], only the Modern Demotic loanword avɣ-ˈo 'egg' is quoted for Prastos.

Northern Tsakonian variant: epsil-ˈe {ἐψιλέ} [Deffner 1923: 399; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 376; Vyatkina 2015: 57]. Directly cognate to Ancient Doric Greek op-tíl-o-s {ὀπτίλος} 'eye', further related to Ionic-Attic opʰ-tʰal-m-ó-s {ὀφθαλμός} 'eye'.

Segments: k s ˈi n ʒ i
Comment: Polysemy: 'fat / hernia'. Cognate to rarely used Modern Greek ksˈiȡ-i {ξύγκι, ξύγγι, ξίγκι, ξίγγι} 'fat' < Medieval Greek {οξύγκιν, αξύγκιν} < late Ancient Greek {αξούγγιον, ὀξύγγιον}, borrowed from Latin {axungia} 'animal fat, usually hog's fat, used as a medicament'. The Tsakonian term is thus likely to be borrowed from Demotic. _x0015_Distinct from pˈaẙ-i {πάχι}, which means specifically 'fat, fatness, portliness' according to the gloss 'πάχος, λίπος / Fett, Beleibtheit / graisse, embonpoint' in [Deffner 1923: 287] (cf. [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 36]). Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek pˈax-o-s {πάχος} 'fatness, portliness'.
Polysemy: 'feather / wing'. Cognate to Modern Demotic fter-ˈo {φτερό}, Ancient Greek pter-ó-n {πτερόν} 'feather / wing'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek eskʰár-a {ἐσχάρα} 'place for a fire', Modern Demotic sxˈar-a {σχάρα} 'grill, frying pan'.

Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek psˈar-i {ψάρι} 'fish', further to Ancient Greek ops-ári-o-n {ὀψάριον} 'foodstuff, esp. fish'. Tsakonian psˈar̝-i looks adapted from Demotic psˈar-i or at least influenced by it.
Cognate to Modern Demotic pet-ˈo {πετώ}, Ancient Greek péto-may {πέτομαι} 'to fly'.
Polysemy: 'foot / leg'. Cognate to Ancient Greek pûː-s, acc. pód-a {ποῦς, πόδα} 'foot' (with ð > 0).

Segments: ʝ o m ˈa t e
Comment: Polysemy: 'full / portly, stout'. Cognate to Modern Demotic yem-ˈat-o- {γεμάτος} 'full', further to Ancient Greek gém-oː {γέμω} 'to be full'. Tsakonian yom-ˈat-e looks adapted from Demotic yem-ˈat-o- or at least influenced by it. In [Vyatkina 2015: 58], the Modern Demotic loanword yem-ˈat-e 'full' is quoted for Prastos.   _x0015_Distinct from xondr-ˈe {χονδρέ, χοντρέ} 'portly, stout' [Deffner 1923: 395; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 354].

Paradigm: ðˈi-u {δίου} [pres.] / e=ðˈu-k-a {ἐδοῦκα} [aor.]. The present stem directly corresponds to Ancient Greek pres. dí=d-oː {δίδω}, a late variant of the more archaic reduplicated dí=doː-mi {δίδωμι}. The aorist form e=ðˈu-k-a corresponds to Ancient Greek aor. é=doː-k-a {ἔδωκα}.

Cf. some examples: "good violets" [Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 187], "good parents" [Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 239], "good grapes" [Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 18], "good road" [Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 18], "good fate" [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 392], "good pieces of wood" [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 402], "We had a good wheat crop this year" [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 412]. Surprisingly, Southern Tsakonian kal-ˈe is glossed only as 'beautiful / virtuous, moral / sufficient, enough' in [Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 18].   _x0015_Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek kal-ˈo- {καλός} 'good', further to Ancient Greek kal-ó- {καλός} 'beautiful / good'. Tsakonian kal-ˈe looks adapted from Demotic kal-ˈo- or at least influenced by it.

Segments: p r ˈa s i n e
Comment: Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek prˈas-in-o- 'green', further to Ancient Greek prás-in-o- {πράσινος} 'leek-green, light green'. Tsakonian prˈas-in-e looks adapted from Demotic prˈas-in-o- or at least influenced by it. In [Vyatkina 2015: 58], only the Modern Demotic loanword prˈas-in-o-a 'green' is quoted for Prastos.

Plural form of sg. čˈix-a {τσ̌ίχα} 'a hair'. A generic term. Cognate to Ancient Greek pl. tríkʰ-es {τρίχες} 'hair'.  _x0015_Distinct from the rarer word korf-ˈa {κορφά} with polysemy: 'top of mountain / head hair' [Deffner 1923: 190] (cf. [Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 109]), cognate to Ancient Greek korüpʰ-éː {κορυφή} 'top'.  _x0015_Distinct from šˈit-a {σ̌ίτα} 'parting (of hair)' [Deffner 1923: 347; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 349], cognate to Modern Demotic ẙˈet-i {χαίτη} 'mane'.

Polysemy: 'hand / arm'. Cognate to Ancient Greek kʰéyr {χείρ}, acc. kʰêyr-a ~ kʰér-a {χεῖρα, χέρα}'hand'. _x0015_Distinct from pˈam-a ~ apˈam-a {πάμα, ἀπάμα} 'palm of hand' [Deffner 1923: 33, 277; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 6], cognate to Ancient Greek palám-eː {παλάμη} 'palm of hand'.
Gen.: cʸufˈal-ˈi. The Northern Tsakonian variant is cʸufˈal-a {τζουφάλα} 'head'. Kostakis and Vyatkina transcribe these forms with initial c {τσ}. Cognate to Ancient Greek kepʰal-éː {κεφαλή} 'head'.

Cognate to Ancient Greek noé-oː {νοέω} 'to perceive by the eyes, perceive by the mind', Modern Demotic ɲˈoθ-o {νοιώθω} 'to understand; to perceive'. It should be noted that the Ancient Greek dialectal contracted variant no-ôː {νοῶ} of the same verb is also reflected as Southern Tsakonian no-ˈu {νοού} 'to perceive; to understand; to remember' [Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 303].  _x0015_Distinct from the verb for 'to listen': aɣr̝ik-ˈu {ἀγρ́οικοῦ} [Deffner 1923: 7], ɣžik-ˈu ~ ɣrik-ˈu {γζ̌ικού, γρικού} [Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 246], cognate to Modern Demotic aɣrik-ˈo ~ ɣrik-ˈo {αγροικώ, γροικώ} 'to listen'.  _x0015_Distinct from the fossilized imperative form ˈako {ἄκο} 'hey, listen' [Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 41], cognate to Modern Demotic akˈu-o {ακούω}, Ancient Greek akúː-oː {ἀκούω} 'to hear'.

Segments: k a r ð ˈi a
Comment: Cognate to Ancient Greek kard-í-aː {καρδία} 'heart'.

Segments: ʨ ˈe r a t e
Comment: Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek ȶˈera-t-o {κέρατο} 'horn' and Ancient Greek kéra-s {κέρας}, dialectal pl. kéra-t-a {κέρατα} 'horn'. Tsakonian cʸˈera-t-e might be adapted from Demotic ȶˈera-t-o or at least influenced by it, but the variant cʸˈera, quoted by Kostakis, should be more archaic.  _x0015_A second, more marginal, term is kˈal-i {κάλ̣ι} with polysemy: 'wood, timber / horn (e.g., of dear)' [Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 19], cognate to Ancient Greek kâːl-o-n {κᾶλον} 'wood, timber'.

Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek ȶˈera-t-o {κέρατο} 'horn' and Ancient Greek kéra-s {κέρας}, dialectal pl. kéra-t-a {κέρατα} 'horn'. Tsakonian cʸˈera-t-e might be adapted from Demotic ȶˈera-t-o or at least influenced by it, but the variant cʸˈera, quoted by Kostakis, should be more archaic.  _x0015_A second, more marginal, term is kˈal-i {κάλ̣ι} with polysemy: 'wood, timber / horn (e.g., of dear)' [Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 19], cognate to Ancient Greek kâːl-o-n {κᾶλον} 'wood, timber'.
Paradigm: ezˈu [nom.] / eɲˈi ~ eɲˈi-u [acc., gen.]. Directly cognate to Ancient Greek egóː {ἐγώ} [nom.] / emóy {ἐμοί} [dat.] 'I'.

Segments: s k o t ˈu n u
Comment: Apparently this is the most common and neutral equivalent for 'to kill'. Directly corresponds to the basic Modern Demotic Greek verb skotˈo-n-o {σκοτώνω} 'to kill'. The Tsakonian verb was thus adapted from the Demotic new formation or at least influenced by it. It must be noted that the Ancient Doric Greek verb for 'to kill' was likely ktéyn-oː {κτείνω}, used by Pindar (O. 2: 38, O. 7: 29, P. 4: 249, I. 6: 48) and Bacchylides (Ep. 5: 89, Dith. 19: 31, also Ep. 5: 128); a more specific one seems to be the verb tʰéyn-oː {θείνω} 'to strike', used by Pindar for 'to kill' (P. 10: 46, P. 11: 37, I. 5: 39, etc.).  _x0015_More marginal Southern Tsakonian verbs with the meaning 'to kill' are θanatˈu-kʰ-u {θανατούκ̔ου} [Deffner 1923: 147; Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 325] (denominative from θˈanate {θάνατε} 'death') and pe=na-ˈix-u {πεναΐχου} [Deffner 1923: 287; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 37] (causative from the basic verb pe=nˈa-kʰ-u {πενάκ̔ου} 'to die' q.v.).

Plural: ɣˈun-i ~ ɣˈun-at-a {γούν̣οι, γούνατα}. The singular form ɣˈun-a is apparently a back formation from the Ancient Greek plural form gúːn-at-a {γούνατα} of gónü {γόνυ} 'knee'. In [Vyatkina 2015: 58], only the Modern Demotic loanword ɣˈon-at-o 'knee' is quoted for Prastos.

Glossed as 'wissen / savoir' by Deffner. Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek ks=ˈer-o {ξέρω} 'to know', further to Ancient Greek eks=ewr-í-sk-oː {ἐξευρίσκω} 'to find out, discover'. Tsakonian ks=ˈer-u looks adapted from Demotic ks=ˈer-o or at least influenced by it.  _x0015_Distinct from ɲir̝ˈiz-u ~ ɲužˈiz-u {νοιρ́ίζου, νιουζ̌ίζου} [Deffner 1923: 247; Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 238] 'to know (an object)', glossed as 'kennen / connaître' by Deffner. Cognate to Ancient Greek gnoː-rízd-oː {γνωρίζω} 'to make known, point out; to gain knowledge of, become acquainted with'.
Plural: fˈi-a {φύα}. Cognate to Ancient Greek pʰǘll-o-n {φύλλον} 'leaf'.

Segments: ʦ a p r ˈu kʰ u
Comment: The Northern Tsakonian stem variant: c=aplˈu-n-u {τσαπλούνου}. Cognate to Modern Demotic ks=aplˈo-n-o {ξάπλωνω} 'to lie', further to Ancient Greek eks=apló-oː {ἐξαπλόω} 'to unfold, roll out'. Tsakonian c=aprˈu-kʰ-u ~ c=aplˈu-n-u looks adapted from Demotic ks=aplˈo-n-o or at least influenced by it.
Borrowed from Demotic sikˈot-i 'liver', further to the word for 'fig (fruit)'.

Directly cognate to Modern Demotic Greek makr-ˈi- {μακρύς} 'long', further to Ancient Greek mak-r-ó- {μακρός} 'long' (with another thematic vowel). Tsakonian makr̝-ˈu looks adapted from Demotic makr-ˈi- or at least influenced by it.
Cognate to Modern Demotic psˈir-a {ψείρα}, Ancient Greek pʰtʰéyr {φθείρ} 'louse'. Tsakonian psˈir-a looks adapted from Demotic psˈir-a or at least influenced by it.
Polysemy: 'man / husband / person'. Cognate to Ancient Greek ántʰroːp-o-s {ἄνθρωπος} 'person', Modern Demotic Greek ˈanθrop-o-s {άνθρωπος} 'person'.

In [Vyatkina 2015: 58], the plural form is transcribed as pˈaši. An adjectival stem. Polysemy: 'many / much / whole / every'. Cognate to Ancient Greek nom. sg. m. pâːs {πᾶς} (< *pant-s, pl. pánt-es {πάντες}) 'all' q.v.   _x0015_There are two Southern Tsakonian adjectives for the meaning 'many':   _x0015_1) pˈas-e {πᾶσε} [Deffner 1923: 284; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 30], cf. Deffner's and Kostakis' examples: "many men", "many fishes", "He knows many things", "a lot of money", "There were many tomatoes". In female gender, pˈas-a {πᾶσα} retains the old meanings 'whole; every', cf. the examples: "I said you the whole truth", "every woman", "every day".   _x0015_2) pers-ˈe {περσέ} [Deffner 1923: 289; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 45], cf. Deffner's and Kostakis' examples: "many men", "many ships", "many times", "a lot of effort", "Last year we had a lot of pears", "many children", "a lot of beans".   _x0015_Kostakis explicitly defines pˈas-e and pers-ˈe as synonyms for 'many'. We follow suit.
An adjectival stem. Polysemy: 'many / much / very'. Cognate to Ancient Greek periss-ó- {περισσός} 'beyond the regular number or size, prodigious'.

Polysemy: 'meat / vagina'. Cognate to Modern Demotic krˈeas {κρέας}, Ancient Greek kréas {κρέας} 'meat'. _x0015_Distinct from sˈark-a {σάρκα} 'flesh (of body)' [Deffner 1923: 319] (not found in [Kostakis 1986-1987]), cognate to Ancient Greek sárk-s {σάρξ} 'flesh'.

Segments: f e ŋ ɡ ˈa r̝ i
Comment: Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek fegˈar-i {φεγγάρι} 'moon', further to Ancient Greek pʰéng-os {φέγγος, -εος} 'light'. Tsakonian feŋgˈar̝-i looks adapted from Demotic fegˈar-i or at least influenced by it.   _x0015_Distinct from mˈin-a {μῆνα} 'month' [Deffner 1923: 233; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 236], cognate to Modern Demotic mˈin-as {μήνας} 'month', Ancient Greek méːn-eː {μήνη} 'moon / month'.

Of unclear origin, cf. Ancient Greek tʰíː-s, gen. tʰiːn-ós {θίς, θινός} 'heap / beach, shore, sand-bank' (tʰ > Tsakonian š is irregular); according to another hypothesis, šˈin-a is cognate to Ancient Greek r̥iːn- {ῥίς} 'nose', which is better phonetically, but less convincing semantically.  _x0015_Distinct from the more specific vrˈax-o {βράχο} 'cliff, rock, mountain' [Deffner 1923: 79; Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 203], cognate to or rather borrowed from Demotic vrˈax-o-s {βράχος} 'cliff, rock'.  _x0015_In [Vyatkina 2015: 59], only the Modern Demotic loanword vun-ˈe 'mountain' is quoted for Prastos.
Cognate to Ancient Greek stóm-a {στόμα} 'mouth'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek ónom-a {ὄνομα} 'name'. In [Vyatkina 2015: 59], only the Modern Demotic loanword ˈonom-a 'name' is quoted for Prastos.

Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek lem-ˈo-s {λαιμός} 'neck', further to Ancient Greek laym-ó-s {λαιμός} 'throat, gullet'. Tsakonian lem-ˈo looks adapted from Demotic lem-ˈo-s or at least influenced by it. In [Vyatkina 2015: 59], only the Modern Demotic loanword lem-ˈo-s 'neck' is quoted for Prastos.

Segments: ʨ i n ˈu r ʨ e
Comment: Cognate to Modern Demotic ȶenˈury-o- {καινούργιος ~ καινούριος} 'new', Ancient Greek kayn-úːrg-i-o- {καινούργιος} 'newly made'. Tsakonian cʸinˈurcʸ-e looks adapted from Demotic ȶen-ˈury-o- or at least influenced by it.   _x0015_Distinct from nˈe-o {νέο} 'young person' [Deffner 1923: 244; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 294], cognate to Ancient Greek né-o- {νέος} 'new'. Surprisingly, in [Vyatkina 2015: 59], nˈe-o is quoted as the basic Tsakonian adjective for 'new'.

Segments: ʨ i r n ˈu ʨ i
Comment: Cognate to Modern Demotic ȶenˈury-o- {καινούργιος ~ καινούριος} 'new', Ancient Greek kayn-úːrg-i-o- {καινούργιος} 'newly made'. Tsakonian cʸinˈurcʸ-e looks adapted from Demotic ȶen-ˈury-o- or at least influenced by it.   _x0015_Distinct from nˈe-o {νέο} 'young person' [Deffner 1923: 244; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 294], cognate to Ancient Greek né-o- {νέος} 'new'. Surprisingly, in [Vyatkina 2015: 59], nˈe-o is quoted as the basic Tsakonian adjective for 'new'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek nǘkt- {νύξ} 'night'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek r̥ünkʰ-os {ῥύγχος, -εος} 'snout, muzzle, beak'.

Cognate to Ancient Greek uː ~ uːk ~ uːkʰ {οὐ ~ οὐκ ~ οὐχ} 'not'. Analytical verbal forms such as pres., imperf. and some others, which consist of the auxiliary verb ˈe- / ˈi- 'to be' + the participle, use the special forms of the verb 'to be': ˈo- / ˈu- 'not to be' [Pernot 1934: 222, 223] resulting from the contraction u-e > o, u-i > u. The vocalic element o was later generalized as a generic exponent of negation of assertion.  _x0015_Prohibitive is expressed by the particle mi ~ min {μὴ, μὴν} [Deffner 1923: 233; Pernot 1934: 295; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 236], borrowed from or at least influenced by the Demotic Greek prohibitive particle mi ~ min, since the expected Southern Tsakonian outcome should be **ɲi ~ ɲin.

Suppletive paradigm: ˈen-a [masc.] / ɲˈi-a [fem.] / en-ˈu [neut.] {ἕνα / νία / ἐνού}. Cognate to Ancient Greek hey-s, hen- [masc.] / mía [fem.] / hen [neut.] {εἷς / μίᾰ / ἕν} '1' and Modern Demotic ˈen-a-s [masc.] / mˈia [fem.] / ˈen-a [neut.] {ένας / μία / ένα} '1'.

Polysemy: 'person / man / husband'; cognate to Ancient Greek ántʰroːp-o-s {ἄνθρωπος} 'person'. That ˈačop-o is the basic term for 'person, human being' in the Prastos and Melana subdialects is proposed in [Vyatkina 2015]. In [Deffner 1923: 57; Pernot 1934: 163], Tsakonian ˈačop-o {ἄτσ̌ωπο} is glossed as 'man (male human being) / husband' or simply 'husband'. _x0015_According to [Deffner 1923: 10; Pernot 1934: 163], the meaning 'person, human being' is expressed by Southern Tsakonian ˈaθrop-o {ἄνθρωπο}, borrowed from Demotic Greek ˈanθrop-o-s {άνθρωπος} 'person'. In [Vyatkina 2015: 59], however, the slot 'person' is filled by ˈanθrop-o only for the Tyros subdialect. _x0015_Cf. [Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 83] without semantic differentiation between ˈaθrop-o and ˈačop-o.

Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek vroẙ-ˈi {βροχή} 'rain', further to Ancient Greek brokʰ-éː {βροχή} 'rain / moistening / inundation', brékʰ-oː {βρέχω} 'to wet'. Tsakonian vrˈex-o looks influenced by Demotic vroẙ-ˈi.

Segments: k o ʦ i n ˈe
Comment: Cognate to Modern Demotic kˈoȶin-o- {κόκκινος} 'red', further to Ancient Greek kókkin-o- {κόκκῐνος} 'scarlet'. Tsakonian kocin-ˈe looks like adapted from Demotic kˈoȶin-o- or at least influenced by it.

Cognate to Ancient Greek poréy-aː {πορεία} 'mode of walking or running, gait; journey; course'. _x0015_There also exists a rare synonym: ðrˈom-o {δρόμο} 'road' [Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 279], recently borrowed from Demotic ðrˈom-o-s {δρόμος} 'road'. _x0015_Distinct from sˈirm-a {σύρμα} 'path, trail' [Deffner 1923: 343; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 210], cognate to Ancient Greek súrm-a {σύρμα} 'anything trailed or dragged; dragging, trailing motion'.
Cognate to Modern Demotic rˈiz-a {ρίζα}, Ancient Greek r̥ízd-aː {ῥίζα} 'root'.

Segments: s t r o n ʒ i l ˈe
Comment: In [Vyatkina 2015], transcribed as stroǯ-il-ˈe. Polysemy: 'round 3D / round 2D'. Cognate to Ancient Greek strong-ǘl-o- {στρογγύλος} 'round 3D', Modern Demotic stroȡ-il-ˈo- {στρογγυλός} 'round 3D / round 2D'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek ámm-o-s {ἄμμος} 'sand', Modern Demotic ˈam-o-s {άμμος} 'sand'. In [Vyatkina 2015: 59], only the Modern Demotic loanword ˈam-o-s 'sand' is quoted for Prastos.

The Northern Tsakonian variant is lal-ˈu {λαλοῦ}. Etymologically glossed by Deffner as 'to talk', but as basic 'to say' by Pernot; the latter is confirmed by numerous textual examples in [Deffner 1923; Kostakis 1986-1987]. Suppletive paradigm: a-ˈu {ἀοῦ} [pres., imperf.] / al(i)- {ἀƛη-} [imv., subj., passive] / e=pˈe-k-a {ἐπέκα} [aor.] / pe-k-ˈu {πεκοῦ} [pass. part.]. In [Vyatkina 2015: 59], the Prastos present form is unexpectedly transcribed as ev-ˈu. The stems a-ˈu and ali- are cognate to the Ancient Greek descriptive verb lalé-oː {λαλέω} 'to talk, chat, prattle', later simply 'to speak (= λέγω)', Modern Demotic lal-ˈo {λαλώ} 'to speak; to chat' (with Southern Tsakonian l > 0). The aorist stem pe- is cognate to Ancient Greek aorist êyp-a {εἶπα} 'to say', Modern Demotic aorist ˈip-a 'to say'. Tsakonian suppletive aorist pe- looks adapted from the Demotic suppletive form ˈip-a or at least influenced by it.  _x0015_Distinct from ɲ-ˈu {νι̰οῦ} 'to speak' [Deffner 1923: 245], cognate to Modern Demotic mil-ˈo {μιλώ} 'to speak', Ancient Greek homiːlé-oː {ὁμιλέω} 'to be in company with, consort with; to converse with' (mʸ > ɲ, l > 0).

Cognate to Ancient Greek horá-oː ~ hor-ôː {ὁράω, ὁρῶ} 'to see'. _x0015_Distinct from ks=ikˈa-z-u {ξεικάζου} 'to look' [Deffner 1923: 255; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 325], cognate to Ancient Greek eks=eyká-zd-oː {ἐξεικάζω} 'to make like, adapt'.

The form pʰlˈam-a is from [Vyatkina 2015]. Polysemy: 'seed / sperm'. Cognate to Ancient Greek spér-m-a {σπέρμα} 'seed'.  _x0015_Distinct from pʰˈur-e {π̔οῦρε} with polysemy: 'a grain, granule / stone of fruit / pimple, pustule' [Deffner 1923: 307; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 177], cognate of Modern Greek spir-ˈi {σπυρί} 'a grain, granule / pimple, pustule', a diminutive from Ancient Greek püːr-ó-s ~ spüːr-ó-s {πυρός, σπυρός} 'wheat, a grain of wheat'.

Segments: k a s ˈi m e n e
Comment: In [Vyatkina 2015], the Prastos form is transcribed with š for s. Directly cognate to the Ancient Greek participle katʰ=éː-men-o- {καθήμενος} 'sitting' from kátʰ=eː-may {κάθημαι} 'to sit' (Modern Demotic kˈaθ=o-me {κάθομαι} 'to sit'). _x0015_Distinct from kacˈe-n-u {κατσαίνου} 'to sit down' [Deffner 1923: 176; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 64], perhaps cognate to Ancient Greek katʰ=ízd-oː {καθίζω} 'to make sit / to sit down' (Modern kaθ=ˈiz-o {καθίζω} 'id.'), where -z- was reanalyzed as a verbal suffix and replaced with another suffix -n-.

Said of humans. It seems that cʸˈep-a is the normal equivalent for 'human skin' in Southern Tsakonian, although examples are scanty. Cognate to Ancient Greek skép-eː {σκέπη} 'covering, shelter, protection'. In [Vyatkina 2015: 59], only the Modern Demotic loanword ðˈerm-a 'skin' is quoted for Prastos.  _x0015_Distinct from tomˈar̝-i {τομάρ́ι} 'hide, animal skin' [Deffner 1923: 360; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 235], cognate to or rather borrowed from Medieval and Modern Demotic tomˈar-i {τομάρι} 'hide', a diminutive from Ancient Greek tóm-o-s {τόμος} 'slice; peace'.  _x0015_Distinct from rare pec-ˈi {πετσί} 'skin' or 'hide', explained in [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 50] as a synonym of tomˈar̝-i; borrowed from Demotic pec-ˈi {πετσί} 'skin, hide'.

_x0015_According to [Pernot 1934], the paradigm is purely suppletive: kasˈi-u {κασήου} [pres., imperfective] / e=ȶˈuv-a {ἐκι̰οῦβα} [aor.] / ȶˈup-s-e {κι̰ούψε} [perfective imv., perfective subjunctive] / ȶuf-t-ˈe {κι̰ουφτέ} [passive pcpl.]. However, in [Deffner 1923: 182; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 76] the additional present form ȶˈuf-u {κι̰ούφου} is also quoted. In [Vyatkina 2015: 59], ȶˈuf-u is offered as the only present form in Southern Tsakonian.  _x0015_The stem kasˈi- is directly cognate to Ancient Greek katʰ=éwd-oː {καθεύδω} 'to lie down to sleep', cf. the apparently Laconian variant {κασεύδει}, quoted by Hesychius.  _x0015_The root ȶuv- / ȶuf- / ȶup- is cognate to the Ancient Greek root küpʰ- attested as küp-t-oː {κύπτω} 'to bend forward, stoop'.  _x0015_We treat Southern Tsakonian pres. kasˈi-u and aor. e=ȶˈuv-a as synonyms, although it seems that in modern language the present root kasi- is already superseded with the preterite ȶuv-.
With change of the stem vowel, cognate to Ancient Doric & Boeotian Greek miːkk-ó- {μικκός} 'small', Ionic-Attic (s)miːk-r-ó- {(σ)μικρός} 'small'.

Segments: k a p i n ˈe
Comment: Cognate to Ancient Greek kap-n-ó-s {καπνός}, Modern Demotic kapn-ˈo-s {καπνός} 'smoke'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek kap-n-ó-s {καπνός}, Modern Demotic kapn-ˈo-s {καπνός} 'smoke'.

Paradigm: stˈe-k-u {στέκου} [pres.] / e=stˈa-m-a {ἐστάμα} [aor.]. Cognate to Modern Demotic stˈe-k-o-me {στέκομαι} 'to stand', further to the Ancient Greek perfect form hé=steː-k-a {ἕστηκα}. The Tsakonian verb looks adapted from Demotic or at least influenced by it.

Plural: ˈašy-a ~ ˈaš-a. The Northern Tsakonian variant is ˈašȶ-i ~ ˈač-i {ἄσ̌κι, άτσ̌ι} 'star'. Cognate to rare Modern Demotic ˈastr-o {άστρο} 'star', Ancient Greek ástr-o-n {ἄστρον} 'star' (derived from the primary noun astéːr {ἀστήρ} 'star'). _x0015_Distinct from astˈer̝i {ἀστέρ́ι} 'small star' [Deffner 1923: 54; Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 149], borrowed from Demotic astˈer-i {αστέρι} 'star'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek pétr-o-s {πέτρος} 'stone', Modern Demotic pˈetr-a {πέτρα} 'stone'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek héːl-i-o-s {ἥλιος}, Modern Demotic ˈiʎ-o-s {ήλιος} 'sun'.

Initial a- is not entirely clear. Applied to humans, animals. Cognate to Ancient Greek plé-oː {πλέω} 'to sail, go by sea'.   _x0015_It must be noted that there is also a Tsakonian verb prˈe-u 'to leak, ooze, be leaky' [Deffner 1923: 301], which phonetically fits Ancient Greek plé-oː {πλέω} 'to sail' better than plˈe-u. Another hypothetical Ancient Greek cognate of Tsakonian prˈe-u 'to leak' is pné-oː {πνέω} 'to blow / to breath'. In [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 67], the Tsakonian verbs plˈe-u and prˈe-u are not discriminated!   _x0015_Distinct from the nearly synonymous verb koʎumb-ˈu ~ kuʎumb-ˈiz-u {κολι̰ουμποῦ, κουλιουμπίζου} 'to swim' [Deffner 1923: 186; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 122], adapted from Demotic kolib-ˈo {κολυμπώ} 'to swim' or at least influenced by it.   _x0015_In [Vyatkina 2015: 60], only the Modern Demotic loanword koʎimb-ˈu 'to swim' is quoted for Prastos.

Initial a- is not entirely clear. Applied to humans, animals. Cognate to Ancient Greek plé-oː {πλέω} 'to sail, go by sea'.   _x0015_It must be noted that there is also a Tsakonian verb prˈe-u 'to leak, ooze, be leaky' [Deffner 1923: 301], which phonetically fits Ancient Greek plé-oː {πλέω} 'to sail' better than plˈe-u. Another hypothetical Ancient Greek cognate of Tsakonian prˈe-u 'to leak' is pné-oː {πνέω} 'to blow / to breath'. In [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 67], the Tsakonian verbs plˈe-u and prˈe-u are not discriminated!   _x0015_Distinct from the nearly synonymous verb koʎumb-ˈu ~ kuʎumb-ˈiz-u {κολι̰ουμποῦ, κουλιουμπίζου} 'to swim' [Deffner 1923: 186; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 122], adapted from Demotic kolib-ˈo {κολυμπώ} 'to swim' or at least influenced by it.   _x0015_In [Vyatkina 2015: 60], only the Modern Demotic loanword koʎimb-ˈu 'to swim' is quoted for Prastos.

Cognate to Ancient Greek uːr-áː {οὐρά} 'tail', Modern Demotic ur-ˈa {ουρά} 'tail'. Initial n- in nur-ˈa is the result of reanalysis of the combination acc. sg. urˈa + definite article tan: tan urˈa > tanurˈa > ta-nurˈa (as from tan-nurˈa) > nurˈa. This word is also attested with initial n- in some other Greek varieties.

Cognate to Ancient Greek uːr-áː {οὐρά} 'tail', Modern Demotic ur-ˈa {ουρά} 'tail'. Initial n- in nur-ˈa is the result of reanalysis of the combination acc. sg. urˈa + definite article tan: tan urˈa > tanurˈa > ta-nurˈa (as from tan-nurˈa) > nurˈa. This word is also attested with initial n- in some other Greek varieties.

Of unclear origin. Some authors suggest Ancient Doric Greek têːn-o- {τῆνος} 'he, she, it' as a starting point; however, this could face phonetic difficulties [Pernot 1934: 209-210].    _x0015_According to [Pernot 1934: 191], the Southern Tsakonian system is ternary. There are two pronouns of proximal deixis: ˈenderi ~ ˈendeni glossed as 'this here' and ˈeteni glossed as 'this there', plus the pronoun of distal deixis etˈine 'that'. We treat the first two forms as synonyms for 'this'.

Segments: ˈe n d e r i
Comment: Glossed as 'this here'. Perhaps goes back to the Ancient Greek preposition/adverb entós {ἐντός} 'within, inside', cf. [Pernot 1934: 207-209].

Segments: ˈe n d e n i
Comment: Glossed as 'this here'. Perhaps goes back to the Ancient Greek preposition/adverb entós {ἐντός} 'within, inside', cf. [Pernot 1934: 207-209].

Glossed as 'this there'. Of unclear origin; according to [Pernot 1934: 207, 209], may be contracted from the Medieval Greek emphatic particle {ἔδε} and the pronoun {αὐτός} 'this': {ἔδε αὐτός} > {ἔδε τός} > {ἔτος} > ˈet-.

Paradigm: eȶˈu [nom.] / etˈi ~ etˈi-u [acc., gen.]. Cognate to the Doric pronominal paradigm tü {τύ} [nom.] / ten ~ teûː ~ tíoː {τεν, τεοῦ, τίω} [gen.] 'thou'. Initial e- in Tsakonian is due to analogy with other personal pronouns: ezˈu / eɲˈi ~ eɲˈi-u 'I', eɲˈi / emˈu-nane 'we', etc.
Polysemy: 'tongue / language'. Cognate to Ancient Greek glôːss-a {γλῶσσα}, Modern Demotic ɣlˈos-a {γλώσσα} 'tongue'.
Cognate to the Ancient Greek oblique stem odónt- {ὀδόντ-} of the basic term odúː-s {ὀδούς} 'tooth' (with ð > 0).

Segments: ð e n ʤ i k ˈo
Comment: Cognate to the Ancient Greek adjective dendr-ik-ó- {δενδρικός} 'of a tree' from déndr-o-n {δένδρον} 'tree'. The Northern Tsakonian form is ðˈenǯ-i {δέντζ̌ι} 'tree' [Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 257].
The more rare emphatic form is ðˈiu {δύου}. Cognate to Ancient Greek dǘo {δύο} 'two'.

Suppletive paradigm: ˈeŋg-u {ἕγκου} [pres., imperf., imperfective subjunctive] / e=zˈa-k- {ἐζᾶκα} [aor.] / zˈa- {να ζάου} [perfective subjunctive] / ˈeʒe {ἕντζε} [imperfective imv.] / xˈaɲȡe {χάγκε} [perfective imv.]. Pres. ˈeŋg- and imv. ˈeʒe are apparently cognate to Ancient Greek érkʰ-o-may {ἔρχομαι} 'to come'. Aor. zˈa- is apparently cognate to Ancient Greek dia=báy-n-oː {διαβαίνω} 'to stride, walk or stand with legs apart'. We treat Southern Tsakonian pres. ˈeŋg-u and aor. e=zˈa-k- as synonyms.

Paradigm: ˈi-o {ὕω} [nom.-acc.] / iv-ˈat-u {ὑβάτου} [gen.]. Directly cognate to Ancient Greek hǘd-oːr {ὕδωρ} [nom.] / hǘd-at-os {ὕδατος} [gen.] 'water' (ð > 0). Because of i instead of Doric u, Tsakonian ˈi-o is expected to be borrowed from early Koine or at least influenced by it.
Paradigm: eɲˈi [nom.] / emˈu-nane ~ eɲˈi-nane [acc., gen.]. Cognate to Ancient Greek heːmêy-s {ἡμεῖς} 'we'.

Segments: e m ˈu n a n e
e ɲ ˈi n a n e

Comment: In [Vyatkina 2015], transcribed as ce. Cognate to Ancient Greek tí {τί} 'what?'.
Cognate to Modern Demotic lefk-ˈo- {λευκός} 'white', Ancient Greek lewk-ó- {λευκός} 'white'.

Cognate to Modern Demotic Greek py-ˈo- {ποιός} 'who?', further to Ancient Greek interrogative pôy-o- {ποῖος} 'of what kind?'. Tsakonian pˈi-e looks adapted from Demotic py-ˈo- or at least influenced by it.  _x0015_The second candidate is archaic ci {τσί} (directly cognate to Ancient Greek tí-s {τίς} 'who?' and tí {τί} 'what?'), whose normal meaning is 'what?' q.v., but according to examples in [Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 269; Pernot 1934: 197], ci {τσί} can sometimes be used as animated 'who?', especially in oblique cases.

Segments: ɣ u n ˈe k a
Comment: Polysemy: 'woman / wife'. Cognate to the Ancient Greek oblique stem günayk- {γυναικ-} of gün-éː {γυνή} 'woman' (retains Doric u for ü, but morphologically apparently influenced by Demotic yinˈek-a {γυναίκα} 'woman').

Segments: ʨ ˈi t r̝ i n e
Comment: Borrowed from Demotic Greek ȶˈitrin-o- {κίτρινος} 'yellow'.

Segments: a l ˈa r ɣ a
Comment: Borrowed from Modern Demotic alˈarɣa {αλάργα} 'far away', ultimately from Medieval Italian {alla larga}.  _x0015_The second, apparently marginal adverb for 'far' is makrˈia {μακρ̣ία} [Deffner 1923: 222; Kostakis 1986-1987, 2: 206; Vyatkina 2015: 60], which looks adapted from Demotic makryˈa {μακριά} 'far' or at least influenced by it (further to 'long' q.v.). The Southern Tsakonian form is only quoted by Deffner and Vyatkina, whereas Kostakis documents makrˈa {μακρά} 'far' for the Propontic dialect.
In [Vyatkina 2015: 60], quoted as var-ˈie. Cognate to Ancient Greek bar-ǘ- {βᾰρύς}, Modern Demotic var-ˈi- {βαρύς} 'heavy'.

Cognate to Modern Demotic kodˈa {κοντά} 'near', late Ancient Greek kont-ó- ~ kond-ó- {κοντός, κονδός} 'short'. Tsakonian kondˈa looks adapted from Demotic kodˈa or at least influenced by it.   _x0015_Distinct from the more specific adverb ðˈipa {δίπα} 'nearby' [Deffner 1923: 108; Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 268], directly cognate to Modern Demotic ðˈipla {δίπλα} 'nearby', Ancient Greek dipló-o- {διπλόος} 'twofold, double'.

In [Vyatkina 2015], transcribed as ˈač-i. Northern Tsakonian: alˈac-i {ἁλάτσι} 'salt'. Directly cognate to Modern Demotic alˈat-i {αλάτι} 'salt', diminutive from Ancient Greek hál-s {ἅλς} 'salt'. Tsakonian ˈac-i looks adapted from Demotic alˈat-i or at least influenced by it.
Cognate to Modern Demotic kod-ˈo- {κοντός} 'short', Ancient Greek kont-ó- ~ kond-ó- {κοντός, κονδός} 'short'. Tsakonian kond-ˈe looks adapted from Demotic kod-ˈo- or at least influenced by it.
Directly cognate to Ancient Greek ópʰ-i-s {ὄφις} 'snake'.
Directly cognate to Ancient Greek ópʰ-i-s {ὄφις} 'snake'.

_x0015_Two adjectives with the meaning 'thin' are quoted in [Deffner 1923; Kostakis 1986-1987] without additional semantic specifications:  _x0015_1) ften-ˈe {φτενέ} [Deffner 1923: 386; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 318]. According to Kostakis' Southern Tsakonian examples, ften-ˈe could mean specifically 'thin 2D': "thin leaf", "thin flat bread", also "fine chopped straw" and "svelte goat". Cognate to Modern Demotic ften-ˈo- {φτενός} 'thin', further to Ancient Greek pteːn-ó- {πτηνός} (Doric ptaːn-ó- {πτανός}) 'flying, winged'.  _x0015_2) psil-ˈe {ψιλέ} [Deffner 1923: 400; Kostakis 1986-1987, 3: 376]. According to Kostakis' Southern Tsakonian examples, psil-ˈe could mean specifically 'thin 1D': "thin thread", "thin string", also "thin voice". Cognate to Modern Demotic psil-ˈo- {ψιλός} 'small, fine / thin', further to Ancient Greek psiːl-ó- {ψιλός} 'bare, uncovered'.  _x0015_We treat ften-ˈe and psil-ˈe as synonyms. It must be noted that both Tsakonian adjectives look adapted from Demotic or at least influenced by it.

Cognate to Modern Demotic aˈer-a-s {αέρας} 'wind', further to Ancient Greek aéːr {ἀήρ} 'air'. Tsakonian aˈer-a looks adapted from Demotic aˈer-a-s or at least influenced by it. In [Vyatkina 2015: 61], only the Modern Demotic loanword aˈer-a-s 'wind' is quoted for Prastos.  _x0015_A second candidate is Southern Tsakonian ˈanem-o {ἄνεμο}, glossed as generic 'wind' in [Deffner 1923: 25], but specified as 'strong wind, harmful wind' in [Kostakis 1986-1987, 1: 80]. Cognate to the basic Ancient Greek term áne-m-o-s {ἄνεμος} 'wind'.
A generic term for 'worm' incl. 'earthworm'. Tsakonian kʰˈoak- directly cognate to Ancient Greek skóːleːk-s {σκώληξ} 'worm, earthworm' (with Doric aː for eː).
Cognate to Modern Demotic xrˈon-o-s {χρόνος} 'year', Ancient Greek kʰrón-o-s {χρόνος} 'time'. Tsakonian xrˈon-e looks adapted from Demotic xrˈon-o-s or at least influenced by it.

Segments: p i t ˈu n i
Comment: Polysemy: 'all (omnis) / all (totus)'. Borrowed from Turkish bütün 'all (omnis/totus)'. Proved by various textual instances.  _x0015_A second, also relatively frequent expression for 'all (omnis) / all (totus)' is čip {čίπ} [Dawkins 1916: 671]. According to Dawkins, borrowed from Turkish čep, a "particle used to strengthen the meaning of a word" (not found in the available Turkish sources).

Segments: s t ˈa x t i
Comment: Found in the example: "The gold pieces had become ashes".
Polysemy: 'bark / skin of fruit'. Diminutive from a noun cognate to Modern Demotic fli-ó-s {φλοιός} 'bark'.

Transcribed as čel-ˈe {τσελέ} 'belly' in [Andriotis 1948: 62]. Cf. the examples: "he tied his shirt to their ox's belly. It became (thus) white-spotted. <...> And the woman went up, (and saw) that the ox is white-spotted" [Dawkins 1916: 475], "I caught the hare; I split open its belly. A paper came out" [Dawkins 1916: 535].

Paradigm: mˈeɣ-o [sg.] / mˈeɣ-a [pl.] {μέγο, μέγα} with l > 0. Cf. the examples: "He saw a big tree" [Dawkins 1916: 467], "above his head there is a big bird", "There is also a big fish" [Dawkins 1916: 471]. _x0015_Distinct from ðr-o {δρό} 'big, great' [Dawkins 1916: 597], although glossed simply as 'μεγάλος', i.e., 'big' in [Andriotis 1948: 63] with the example "big men". Cognate to Ancient Greek hadr-ó- {ἁδρός} 'thick, stout, bulky', Modern Demotic Greek aðr-ˈo- {αδρός} 'thick, stout, bulky; dense, thick'.

The only available examples are: "[Wolf,] do not bite me" [Dawkins 1916: 487], "He came upon two snakes. There was a black one and a grey one. The grey one was biting the black one" [Dawkins 1916: 559]. _x0015_Distinct from čend- ~ ǯend- {čένd-, ǰένd-} 'to prick' [Dawkins 1916: 608], applicable to snakes as in the example "It [the snake] will bite me" [Dawkins 1916: 555].
] / ste ~ stˈe-a [pl.] {στό, στέ(α)}; in [Andriotis 1948: 56], the sg. form is quoted as sto-n {στόν}. Polysemy: 'bone / lower leg'. Directly cognate to Ancient Greek osté-o-n {ὀστέον} 'bone'.

Segments: k a r d ˈi a
Comment: Polysemy: 'heart / breast' (in [Dawkins 1916: 607], only with the gloss 'heart'). Cf. Andriotis' example: "hairy chest".

The meaning 'to burn (intrans.)' is expressed by the passive voice of the verb cognate to Ancient Greek káy-oː {καίω} 'to burn (trans. / intrans.)'. Pharasa paradigm: kˈaf-t-o [pres.] / ˈe=kap-s-a [aor. act.] / kˈa-i [aor. pass.] / ka-mˈen-a [ptc. pass.] {κάφτω, ἔκαψα, κάη, καμένα}. Cf. the example: "we went to cut wood; we brought it, we burned it" [Dawkins 1916: 569]. _x0015_Distinct from the Pharasa verb pir-ˈev-o ~ pir-ˈiz-o {πυρέβω, πυρίζω} 'to set fire to' [Dawkins 1916: 638]. Cognate to Ancient Greek pːr {πῦρ} 'fire'.
Cf. the example: "Her nails filled with blood" [Dawkins 1916: 523].

Segments: s ˈi n e f a
Comment: Only the plural form 'clouds' is attested.

Segments: ˈe r x u m e
Comment: Suppletive paradigm: ˈerx-u-me {ἔρχουμαι} [pres.] / ˈirt-a {ἤρτα} [aor.] / ˈea {ἔα} [imv.].

Paradigm: xˈa-n- {χάν-} [pres.] / xˈa-θ-a {χάθα} [aor.]. Normally applicable to humans, esp. Greeks. This is the passive voice from the verb 'to lose', which is used as the most neutral and frequent expression for 'to die', according to the texts in [Dawkins 1916]. Denominative verb from Ancient Greek kʰá-os {χάος, -εος} 'chaos'.  _x0015_A second, probably more rare Pharasa expression for 'to die (of humans)' is the aorist pˈe=θan-e {πέθανε} [Dawkins 1916: 632].  _x0015_Distinct from Pharasa psof-ˈo {ψοφῶ} 'to die', normally applicable to animals or Turks [Dawkins 1916: 663]; cognate to Modern Demotic psof-ˈo {ψοφώ} 'to die (of animals)', Ancient Greek psopʰ-é-oː {ψοφέω} 'to sound, make a noise (like cracked pot, knock, etc.)'.
Aorist: ˈe=p-a {ἔπα}.
Not specified semantically. Cf. also the verb kser-ˈo-n-o {ξερώνω} 'to dry (trans.); to run dry (of liquids)' [Andriotis 1948: 70].
_x0015_Distinct from Pharasa yi {γῆ} 'ground' [Dawkins 1916: 592].
Suppletive paradigm: trˈoɣ-o {τρώγω} [pres.] / ˈe=faɣ-a {ἔφαγα} [aor.].
May originate directly from *ov-o-n < *o-o-n < oːy-o-n.

Segments: f t ˈa l m i
Comment: Directly cognate to Ancient Greek opʰ-tʰal-m-i-on {ὀφθαλμιον}, diminutive from opʰ-tʰal-m-ó-s {ὀφθαλμός} 'eye'.

Glossed as 'fat, butter'. Cf. the examples: "take a feather from my wing, and a little of my [= bird's] fat" [Dawkins 1916: 471], "She made an omelette with twenty eggs. There is not enough fat <...> She went inside to bring fat" [Dawkins 1916: 477]. Cognate to Modern Demotic ˈalim-a {ἄλειμμα} 'smearing with an oily substance / oily substance, lubrication', Ancient Greek áleymm-a {ἄλειμμα, -ατος} 'anything used for anointing, unguent, fat, oil'.
Distinct from paronymous fter-ˈo {φτερό} 'wing' [Dawkins 1916: 658].

Segments: n i s t ˈi a
Comment: Cognate to Ancient Greek hest-í-aː {ἑστία} 'hearth of a house; the house itself, home; altar'. Initial n- is is the result of reanalysis of the combination acc. sg. estˈia + definite article tin: tin estˈia > tinestˈia > ti-nestˈia (as from tin-nestˈia) > nestˈia.

Segments: p e t t ˈa o
Comment: Not a very reliable gloss, but Andriotis probably implies the meaning 'to fly' for this verb. In [Dawkins 1916: 633], pet-ˈa-o is only quoted with polysemy: 'to throw, shoot / to jump', cf. the examples: "He (= the boy) went and jumped into the river. The river became all gold" [Dawkins 1916: 549], "And when he (= the hare) sprang upon the ass, the ass kicked him down" [Dawkins 1916: 557].

Segments: p o r ˈa ð i
Comment: Cognate to Medieval Greek {ποδάρι}, Ancient Greek pod-ár-i-on {ποδάριον}, diminutive from pûː-s {ποῦς} 'foot'.  _x0015_The equivalent for 'leg' is not documented explicitly.

The meaning '(to be) full' is expressed by the passive voice from the verb em-ˈo-n-o {ἐμώνω} 'to fill (trans.)'. Cf. the example: "There were two cauldrons; they were full of gold pieces and silver" [Dawkins 1916: 549].

Cf. the available example: "caught her by the hair" [Dawkins 1916: 513]. _x0015_Distinct from sg. cˈar-i {τσάρι} / pl. cˈar-e {τσάρε} 'a hair, hairs, fur' [Dawkins 1916: 653] with the example: "Granny, you have here a white hair; I will cut it" [Dawkins 1916: 489].

_x0015_Distinct from vrošˈon-i {βροσ̌όνι} 'arm' [Dawkins 1916: 590] (in [Andriotis 1948: 20], transcribed as vrošiˈon-i {βροσιόνι}); cognate to Medieval Greek {βραχιόνι} 'upper arm'. Cf. the example: "My art is, I will shake in my arms the seven mountains; I will lift them up in the air at one effort" [Dawkins 1916: 575]. _x0015_Distinct from xˈuft-a {χούφτα} 'palm of hand, handful' [Dawkins 1916: 661].

Segments: ʧ u f ˈa l i
Comment: The phonetic variant ǯufˈal-i {ǰουφάλι} is even more frequent, according to Dawkins.  _x0015_Additionally, the loanword ȶell-ˈä-s {κελλα̈ς} 'head' is attested [Andriotis 1948: 77] < Turkish kelle 'head'.

Paradigm: kˈuɣ-o [pres. 1 sg.] / ku [pres. 3 sg.] / ˈi=k-s-a [aor.] {κούγω, κού, ἤκσα}. _x0015_Distinct from n=ekrˈu-me {νεκροῦμαι} 'to listen' [Dawkins 1916: 584]. Cf. the examples: "The little boy, however, was listening at the window" [Dawkins 1916: 475], "my son was listening outside" [Dawkins 1916: 477], "My art is, I will listen on the ground, and I know whatever is going on in the world" [Dawkins 1916: 575]. A prefixed (*ana=) counterpart of Modern Demotic akro-ˈo-me {ακροώμαι} 'to listen attentively, heed', Ancient Greek akro-á-o-may ~ akro-á-zd-o-may {ἀκροάομαι, ἀκροάζομαι} 'to hearken, listen to'. _x0015_The rarely used prefixless variant ȶerˈu-me {κεροῦμαι} 'to listen' [Dawkins 1916: 587] is attested in Pharasa as well.

Segments: k a r d ˈi a
Comment: Polysemy: 'heart / breast'. It seems, however, that all textual instances in [Dawkins 1916; Andriotis 1948] concern 'heart' in metaphorical sense only ('organ of feeling' etc.).

Segments: ʦ ˈe r o t o

Comment: Suppletive paradigm: eɣˈo ~ o [nom.] / emˈena [acc.].
Suppletive paradigm: eɣˈo ~ o [nom.] / emˈena [acc.].

Segments: s k o t ˈo n o
Comment: Cf. the examples: "She brought it, to dash it down upon the man, to kill him" [Dawkins 1916: 471], "she may kill her son" [Dawkins 1916: 475], "Man, do not let me come there, lest I kill you" [Dawkins 1916: 479], "He killed her" [Dawkins 1916: 505], "They were killing it (= the snake)" [Dawkins 1916: 507], "go, strike that man, kill him!" [Dawkins 1916: 509], "They killed the man" [Dawkins 1916: 519]. Cognate to Medieval and Modern Demotic skot-ˈo-n-o {σκοτώνω} 'to kill'.  _x0015_A second, equally frequently used verb for 'to kill' is fsˈaɣ-n-o {φσάγνω}, cognate to Ancient Greek spʰázd-oː {σφάζω}, Modern Demotic sfˈaz-o {σφάζω} 'to slay, slaughter'. Despite the fact that skot-ˈo-n-o is likely to be Demotic loanword, we treat both Pharasa verbs as synonyms.  _x0015_Distinct from the more rare Pharasa (and Cappadocian) psof-arˈi-z-o {ψοφαρίζσ} 'to kill', obj. = animals [Dawkins 1916: 663]; derived from psof-ˈo {ψοφῶ} 'to die (of animals or Turks)'.

Segments: f s ˈa ɣ n o
Comment: Cf. the examples: "You have a seven year old barren cow. Kill it" [Dawkins 1916: 477], "Kill this boy; cook him... she would kill the boy" [Dawkins 1916: 489], "he killed the little boy" [Dawkins 1916: 513], "Who has killed the baby?" [Dawkins 1916: 515], "He said to his wife, 'I will pretend to kill you'" [Dawkins 1916: 520], "Afterwards they killed the sheep" [Dawkins 1916: 521], "You must kill this little boy" [Dawkins 1916: 527].

Segments: ɣ ˈo n o t o
Comment: Transcribed as ɣˈon-at-o {γόνατο} by Dawkins.

Segments: k a t ˈe x o
Comment: Polysemy: 'to know / to understand'. Glossed simply as 'to understand' by Dawkins, but actually kat=ˈex-o is the generic verb for 'to know' in Pharasa. Cf. the examples: "The little boy said, 'Mother, my eyes! I cannot see as before'. His mother said, 'Why?' He said, 'How do I know?'" [Dawkins 1916: 477], "He said, 'Wife, come, shall we give our son, shall we sell him?' And the woman said, 'You know best'" [Dawkins 1916: 497], "This little boy, how does he know what dream the king has seen?" [Dawkins 1916: 543], "Your father, I know, will go to his daughters" [Dawkins 1916: 563], "My art is, I will listen on the ground, and I know whatever is going on in the world" [Dawkins 1916: 575]. Cognate to Ancient Greek kat=ékʰ-oː {κατέχω} 'to hold fast, hold back, withhold / to possess, occupy / to control oneself', Medieval Greek {κατέχω} id.
Polysemy: 'leaf / stuffed cabbage roll (a dish)'.

Segments: s i ɡ ˈo t i

Comment: Diminutive from Ancient Greek pʰtʰéyr {φθείρ} 'louse'.

Polysemy: 'man / person / husband'. Back formation from Medieval Greek pl. t. onomˈat-i {ονομάτοι} 'persons, individuals', derived from ˈonom-a, pl. onˈom-at-a {όνομα, ονόματ-} 'name'. This is the basic term for at least 'man' and 'person' in Pharasa. Cf. some examples for the meaning 'man': "The man mounted on the horse. And the little boy mounted on the horse's crupper" [Dawkins 1916: 469], "In a time of old there was a man. He had a wife" [Dawkins 1916: 475]. Cf. some examples for the meaning 'person': "The mother of the chicks came. She saw that a man is sleeping at the root of the poplar" [Dawkins 1916: 471], "Sir, when a man dies and is made whole again, is his oath annulled?" [Dawkins 1916: 473], "The ogres said, '<...> Perhaps there was a man in here'" [Dawkins 1916: 485], "In a time of old there was a man. He had also a wife" [Dawkins 1916: 489], "Afterwards men in the village there heard of it" [Dawkins 1916: 505], "On Sunday a man questioned him" [Dawkins 1916: 517], "In a time of old there were four men" [Dawkins 1916: 465]. For 'husband': "Husband, I shall go to ask God to give us a baby" [Dawkins 1916: 475], "She said to her man (ˈandra), 'Man (ˈe nomˈati), I have discovered what to do'" [Dawkins 1916: 477].  _x0015_The borrowing insˈan-i {ἰνσάνι} 'person' [Dawkins 1916: 665] is also sometimes used, e.g., "He went also to the big apple-trees. He took one from them. He became a donkey. He took one from the next tree. He became a man" [Dawkins 1916: 481].  _x0015_The somewhat infrequent word ˈandr-a-s {ἄνdρας} [Dawkins 1916: 584] apparently means only 'husband' (despite Dawkins' gloss 'man'). Cf. some examples: "She said to her man (ˈandra), 'Man (ˈe nomˈati), I have discovered what to do'" [Dawkins 1916: 477], "In a time of old there were a woman and a man, a little boy and a little girl" [Dawkins 1916: 479], "His wife wrote him a letter; she sent it to Stambul to her husband" [Dawkins 1916: 541].
Plural form: krˈä-t-a ~ krˈä-t-e {κρα̈τα, κρα̈τε} [Dawkins 1916: 164]. Transcribed as kra-s {κράς} by Andriotis.

Segments: f ˈe ŋ ɡ o s
Comment: Directly cognate to Ancient Greek pʰéng-os {φέγγος, -εος} 'light, splendour, lustre (e.g., moonlight)', Medieval Greek {φέγγος} 'light / moon'. The diminutive feŋg-ˈusk-o-s {φεν̣gούσκος} is also used for the meaning 'moon' in Pharasa.  _x0015_Distinct from min {μήν} 'month' [Dawkins 1916: 624].

Of unclear origin, cf. Ancient Greek r̥aːkʰ-í-aː {ῥᾱχία} 'flood-tide; rocky shore or beach' or r̥ákʰ-i-s {ῥάχις} 'lower part of the back, chine; anything ridged like the backbone'.  _x0015_A second, rarely used term for 'mountain' is vuin-ˈi {βουινί} [Dawkins 1916: 589].
Plural: onˈom-at-a {ὀνόματα}.

Segments: ɣ u r ɣ ˈu r i
Comment: Glossed as 'throat' by Dawkins, but actually means 'neck'. Cf. the examples: "she passed the mill-stone over her neck" [Dawkins 1916: 471], "He brought the bird's fat; he anointed his neck with it" [Dawkins 1916: 473], "He fastened it to his wife's neck" [Dawkins 1916: 521]. Cognate to Medieval Greek {γούργουρος} 'throat', Modern Demotic ɣurɣˈur-i ~ ɣurɣˈur-a ~ ɣˈurɣul-a-s {γουργούρι, γουργούρα, γούργουλας} 'throat'; borrowed from Latin {gurgulio} 'throat'.
Borrowed from Turkish dialectal taze ~ teze 'new'.

Segments: n i ˈe x t a

Comment: In [Andriotis 1948: 87], quotes as mit-ˈi-s {μυτής}. Cf. the example: "he blew into his wife's nose" [Dawkins 1916: 521].

Another rare phonetic variant is čo. A particle, denoting negation of assertion. Apparently directly cognate to the Pontic Greek negative particle ȶi {κί} [Dawkins 1916: 609; Andriotis 1948: 88], Ancient Ionic Greek uːkí {οὐκί} 'not' (the extended variant of uː ~ uːk ~ uːkʰ 'not'), Medieval Greek {οὐκί} 'not' (one of the several attested variants of the negative particle).  _x0015_Prohibitive is expressed by the particle mu(n) {μούν} [Dawkins 1916: 624] (with more rare variants mi, me {μή, μέ}).
Indeclinable.
Polysemy: 'man / person / husband'. See notes on 'man'.

Segments: l tʰ i n ˈo s
Comment: Directly cognate to Ancient Greek aleːtʰin-ó- {ἀληθινός} 'true, genuine'. Cf. the paronymous Pharasa word ltʰin-ˈusk-a {λτ̔ινούσκα} 'measles, rubeola' [Andriotis 1948: 60]. No expressions for 'red' in [Dawkins 1916].

Segments: s t r ˈa t a
Comment: Cf. the examples: "Whilst they were going on the road, they became hungry" [Dawkins 1916: 483], "Come, let us go and follow this road" [Dawkins 1916: 507], "He sets the blind men in the road; he sets the deaf men in the road" [Dawkins 1916: 539]. Cognate to late Ancient Greek strâːt-aː {στρᾶτα} 'street', borrowed from Latin straː-t-a 'paved street'. The development 'street' > 'road (in general)' is an inner Greek innovation.

Cf. the examples: "Whilst he was going, he went to the root of a poplar-tree" [Dawkins 1916: 469], "she tied them to the root of the pear-tree by their tails" [Dawkins 1916: 501]. _x0015_Differently in [Andriotis 1948: 60], where the word kˈoȶ-i {κόκκι} is glossed as 'root' (cognate to Modern Demotic kuȶ-ˈi {κουκί} 'bean; a grain').

Segments: j u v a r l a x i
Comment: Not specified semantically, perhaps with polysemy: 'round 3D / round 2D'. Borrowed from Turkish yuvarlak 'round 3D'.

Cf. the example: "She brought two loads of sand, and two loads of fine grain" [Dawkins 1916: 473]. Initial n- in nˈam-o-s is the result of reanalysis of a construction with the definite article acc. sg. ton {τον}.

Suppletive paradigm: lˈe- {λέω} [pres., imperf.] / ˈip-a {εἴπα} [aor.] / p-e {πέ} [imv.]. _x0015_Distinct from al-ˈo {ἀλῶ} 'to speak' [Dawkins 1916: 619] (with l- > 0). _x0015_Distinct from gaǯ-ˈev-o {gαǰέβω} 'to speak, talk' [Dawkins 1916: 616], derived from the loanword gaǯ-ˈi {gαǰί} 'word' [Dawkins 1916: 616] < Turkish dial. keleǯi 'word' (with -l- > 0).

Suppletive paradigm: or-ˈo {θωρῶ} [pres.] / ˈið-a {εἴδα} [aor.]. Present or-ˈo is directly cognate to Ancient Greek tʰeoːr-é-oː {θεωρέω} 'to be sent to consult an oracle; to look at, behold'. _x0015_Distinct from ɣrˈev-o {γρέβω} 'to look' [Dawkins 1916: 594], directly cognate to Demotic yirˈev-o {γυρεύω} 'to look for, search', Ancient Greek güːr-éw-oː {γυρεύω} 'to run round in a circle'.
Aorist.

Segments: k ˈa θ o m e
Comment: Polysemy: 'to sit / to sit down'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek hüp-nó-oː {ὑπνόω} 'to put to sleep; to fall asleep' with an additional nasal suffix.

No specific adjectives for 'small' are documented in [Dawkins 1916; Andriotis 1948]. According to available textual evidence, the common way to express the meaning 'small, little' is the nominal diminutive suffix -ˈokk-, for which see [Andriotis 1948: 41-42]. Cf. some examples: "The little birds (pul-ˈokk-a {πουλόκκα}) piped" [Dawkins 1916: 471], "there were a woman and a man, a little boy (fš-ˈokk-o {φσ̌όκκο}) and a little girl (gorʒ-ˈokk-o {gορdζόκκο}). They were poor. The little ones (bešak-ˈokk-a {bεσ̌ακόκκα}) used to go fetch wood" [Dawkins 1916: 479], "They went; they found a nest. There was the little egg (v-ˈokk-o {βόκκο}) of a little bird (bu-ˈokk-u {bουόκκoυ})" [Dawkins 1916: 479], "I have also a little pot (ǯuǯ-ˈokk-o {ǰουǰόκκο}) of gold pieces" [Dawkins 1916: 483], "His wife had a baby, and his horse a colt (tˈai {τάϊ}), and the colt had a little colt (tai-ˈokk-o {ταϊόκκο})" [Dawkins 1916: 489], "Now, - the little loaf (kur-ˈokk-o {κουρόκκο}), grab the little loaf" [Dawkins 1916: 505], "The little poplar-tree (qavaq-ˈokk-o {qαβαqόκκο}) stooped down; she climbed up" [Dawkins 1916: 507], "Afterwards the little fox (ap-ˈokk-o-s {ἀπόκκος}) came. He said to the little axe (pelekað-ˈokk-o {πελεκαδόκκο}) <...>" [Dawkins 1916: 507], "One day, whilst he was going to school, two little boys had a little snake (gulaǯ-ˈokk-o {gουλαǰόκκο})" [Dawkins 1916: 507]. _x0015_The following instance is especially interesting: "'Woman, how well you did to stuff this goose with rice and bring it to me'. And the woman said, 'I found a cheap little (ftinˈus-k-o {φτηνούσκο}) goose; I stuffed it'" [Dawkins 1916: 475]; ftinˈus-k-o means 'cheap and small' being derived from the adjective ftin-ˈo-s {φτηνός} 'cheap', cognate to Modern Demotic efin-ˈo- {ευθηνός} 'cheap' [Dawkins 1916: 658].

Cognate to Medieval Greek and Modern Demotic cˈikn-a {τσίκνα} 'smell of burning'. Perhaps from Ancient Greek knîːs-a {κνῖσα} 'steam and odour of fat which exhales from roasting meat, smell or savour of a burnt sacrifice' via metathesis and irregular s > c. _x0015_The original root for 'smoke' is retained in kˈapn-i {κάπνη} 'hole in the roof to let out the smoke, smoke duct' [Dawkins 1916: 607; Andriotis 1948: 55].

Segments: s t ˈi k n o
Comment: Aorist: stˈa--a {στάθα}. In [Andriotis 1948: 70], the medial voice stˈi-k-n-o-me {στήκνομαι} 'to stand' is quoted, the change of voice is due to influence of Modern Demotic. Cf. the example: "she saw that the little old man is standing in the rain" [Dawkins 1916: 527].

Segments: s t ˈe k n o
Comment: Aorist: stˈa--a {στάθα}. In [Andriotis 1948: 70], the medial voice stˈi-k-n-o-me {στήκνομαι} 'to stand' is quoted, the change of voice is due to influence of Modern Demotic. Cf. the example: "she saw that the little old man is standing in the rain" [Dawkins 1916: 527].

Polysemy: 'stone / rock, cliff'. Cf. some examples: "The little birds piped, 'What are you going to do with this stone?'" [Dawkins 1916: 471], "He filled it (= the wallet) with dog's dung, stones and some thorns" [Dawkins 1916: 487], "The little boys threw stones and clods" [Dawkins 1916: 535], "The woman went to a rock. She prayed. God gave her a baby" [Dawkins 1916: 475]. Directly cognate to Ancient Greek litʰ-ár-i-on {λιθάριον}, Medieval Greek {λιθάρι}, diminutive from lítʰ-o-s {λίθος} 'stone'.  _x0015_Distinct from gaǯ-ˈi {gαǰί} with the more rare variants fkaǯ-ˈi, gˈaǯ-i, gˈač-i {φκαǰί, gάǰι, gάčι}, glossed as 'stone, rock' in [Dawkins 1916: 616]. Only examples for the meaning 'rock, cliff' are available, such as: "She went to a great rock. And the little boy went to the back of the rock" [Dawkins 1916: 477], "They went up to a rock" [Dawkins 1916: 517]. Perhaps cognate to Ancient Greek plak-í-on {πλακίον}, diminutive from plák-s {πλάξ} 'anything flat and broad; flat stone, tablet'.
Cognate to Ancient Greek plé-oː {πλέω} 'to sail, go by sea'.

Cognate to Medieval Greek urˈa-ð-i-n {οὐράδιν}. Cf. some examples: "she tied them (= the foxes) to the root of the pear-tree by their tails" [Dawkins 1916: 501], "If its (= mule's) tail as well were cut off, it would fetch fifty pounds" [Dawkins 1916: 519].  _x0015_The loanword quirˈuẙ-i {qουϊρούχι} 'tail' [Dawkins 1916: 683] is also attested < Turkish kuyruk 'tail'.
According to Dawkins, the system is binary: 'this' / 'that'.
According to Dawkins, the system is binary: 'this' / 'that'.
Polysemy: 'this / he, she, it'. Cognate to Modern Demotic aft-ˈo- {αυτός} 'this / he, she, it', Ancient Greek reflexive awt-ó- {αὐτός} 'self'.
Paradigm: esˈi [nom.] / esˈena [acc.] {ἐσύ, ἐσένα}.

Segments: ð a n d ˈa r i
